title: Global forces give RBA little choice
text:
While RBA had been surprised by the recent softness in GDP growth, a laundry list of gentle tailwinds – including lower interest rates, the recent tax cuts, the weaker Australian dollar and the stabilisation of the housing market – meant the economy was heading for an inflection point.

The good news for the corporate sector was three-fold.

Lowe said experience suggested that half of the enlarged tax refunds flowing through to many households from the low- and middle-income tax offset will be spent over the coming quarters, confirming the predictions of retailers such as JB Hi-Fi’s Richard Murray.

The governor also singled out the resources industry as a bright spot, as the big miners increase their capital expenditure and even start to explore again. “To be clear, we are not predicting a return to boom-time conditions in the resources sector. But we are predicting better times for the sector ahead,” Lowe said.

The third leg is infrastructure spending, which Lowe said is “not only supporting demand in the economy at a time when this is needed, but it is also adding to the supply capacity of the economy and directly improving people’s lives”.

There are two risks to the rosier picture.

Firstly, household consumption - which remained completely flat in the last 12 months - remains hostage to a combination of low income growth and the weakness in the housing market, where a 20-year low in people moving house has seen softness in spending on new furniture and household appliances. Without a pick up in wages, Lowe conceded that the case for a sustained pick-up in household spending is hard to make.

The second risk is the international uncertainties created by trade tensions, Brexit, the problems in Hong Kong and developments in the Middle East.

It is these uncertainties, Lowe said, that are weighing so heavily on global rates. And in an “interconnected world” the RBA has little choice but to “take the world and global interest rates as we find them”.

“Our floating exchange rate gives us a degree of monetary independence, but we can’t ignore structural shifts in global interest rates. If we did seek to ignore these shifts, our exchange rate would appreciate, which, in the current environment, would be unhelpful in terms of achieving both the inflation target and full employment.”

Lowe repeated his view that an extended period of low rates may be needed to “make further progress towards full employment, and achieve the inflation target over time” and the board is ready to cut again if it needs to.

The question, as always, is when. There’s certainly an argument to be had that by forecasting a gentle inflection point in the domestic economy, Lowe is signalling that he can afford to wait just a little longer before cutting again – even in an interconnected world.
description: Philip Lowe says the global downward pressure on rates can't be ignored. But whether another cut is coming as soon as next week is still up in the air.
